description: Via French pastiche, from Italian pasticcio (“pie, something blended”), from Vulgar Latin *pastīcius, from Late Latin pasta (“dough, pastry cake, paste”), from Ancient Greek παστά (pastá, “barley porridge”), from παστός (pastós, “sprinkled with salt”). Doublet of pasticcio.

entries.meaning: A work of art, drama, literature, music, or architecture that imitates the work of a previous artist.
A musical medley, typically quoting other works.

examples: This supposed research paper is a pastiche of passages from unrelated sources.
The house failed to attract a buyer because the decor was a pastiche of Bohemian and Scandinavian styles.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A postmodern playwriting technique that fuses a variety of styles, genres, and story lines to create a new form.

verbs.description: pastiche (third-person singular simple present pastiches, present participle pastiching, simple past and past participle pastiched)

entries.meaning: To create or compose in a mixture of styles.
